newsitem.title: USA: Read-Rite rejects Applied Magnetics offer.
newsitem.headline: Read-Rite rejects Applied Magnetics offer.

text.p: Read-Rite Corp. said Monday it rejected an unsolicited takeover bid worth $1.76 billion from Applied Magnetics Corp., another maker of computer disk drives.
The combined companies would have $1.8 billion in annual sales and an equity capitalisation of $3.4 billion.
Read-Rite, the world's largest independent supplier of recording heads, said its board of directors voted unanimously to reject the offer and remain independent.

"Read-Rite's independence has been critical to its success to date, and we are confident that adherence to our existing, long-term strategic business plan will enable us to deliver further value to our shareholders, employees, customers, suppliers, and the company's other constituencies in the future," said Cyril Yansouni, chairman and chief executive.
In February, Applied Magnetics offered 0.679 share of its common stock, worth about $36, for each Read-Rite share.
Read-Rite, based in Milpitas, Calif., said it hired Goldman, Sachs & Co. as its independent financial adviser.
Read-Rite's stock rose 18.75 cents to $39.875 on Nasdaq at midday. Goleta, Calif.-based Applied Magnetics jumped $3 to $41.875 on the New York Stock Exchange.
